title: Which country will the 2020-21 UEFA Champions League final winner be from?
possible_answers: There will not be a 2020-21 final winner
preds: Um, the only teams left are from England.
Man city Vs Chelsea are the finalists
I know this question technically has a `there will not be a 2020-21 final winner' but imo it should close now because there is no suggestion the final will not take place. Chelsea or City will win.
Man City in form and unbeatable
PSG are out of the game, and as predicted, Chelsea seem to be in a better chance of going to the final. In that case, it would go to a 100% - but not until this evening :)
Easier games for the 2 English clubs at the weekend so should be more rested - Real and PSG also have some injury concerns ahead of second legs (Varane, Mbappe)
Since Man city have a clear advantage vs PSG after first leg SF, and Chelsea advantage over Real Madrid.  Both English clubs in final - and forecast comes true before the final (obviously)
going to be all england final wit Man City to win it

(1) Betting odds has Man City, Real, PSG, and Chelsea at +150, +380, +320, +450 respectively. That translates to (normalized to 100%) odds of 39%, 20%, 23%, and 18%. So 57% England, 20% Spain, 23% France. Link: https://www.oddschecker.com/football/champions-league (2) 538's Elo rating has a more bullish setup for England: 74% England teams, 8% France, 18% Spain. The most different thing about 538 is their bullish view on Chelsea (and they are a bit more strong on Man City as well): https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/soccer-predictions/?ex_cid=rrpromo (3) Lastly a very naive "equal weight" Would suggest 50/25/25 odds.  I weigh the betting odds more heavily, 538 next, then the equal thing least so doing a weighting of 75%,25%,5%, which yields values of: Man City (42%), Real (20%), PSG (19%), Chelsea (18%).

Bounce back to closer to 538 numbers, but removing the possibility of every but PSG getting banned, and adding a big skew to PSG the only side here untainted by the European Super League controversy.  GJO has confirmed if there's no final, this resolves as "no final winner", regardless of a champion being named.
revised numbers based on 538 but a huge tilt in the chances of there being no final or Real, City and Chelsea underperforming in the wake of the Super League controversy.
4 strong teams. I see them almost on eyelevel, with ManCity a little above and Chelsea a little below the average 25%.

I'm very nervous doing this... but to me, it makes sense to divvy up points by proportion of aggregate points scored. In which case, I want to weigh England heavier but this is a fair snapshot of where we stand. Maybe I'll chicken out or learn more in the next 10 days, but on 28 Apr, I have a theory that whoever draws first blood is likely to advance.
Two English clubs in the semis, Chelsea starting to come into proper form.   But Real and PSG are strong, Real knocked out Liverpool (admittedly an out of form Liverpool)

Very likely there will be an all-English final, if PSG loses their first leg of the semifinals on 28 April 2021.
I will only amend forecast if either PSG wins and/or Real Madrid lose their first leg.

En primer lugar, hay que considerar que quedan tan solo 4 equipos aun en competencia, Real Madrid, Paris Saint-Germain, Manchester City F.C. y Chelsea F.C. de los cuales 1 es de España, 1 de Francia y 2 de Inglaterra.  Para evaluar las posibilidades primero hay que analizar la llaves y que factores inciden en el rendimiento del equipo, los mas importantes para mi son experiencia, desgaste por otras competiciones, disponibilidad de la plantilla y forma actual del equipo. Sin lugar a dudas Real Madrid es el equipo con mayor experiencia entre los equipos restantes, pero su desempeño esta perjudicado por las multiples lesiones, su gran desgaste en que va de la Liga y el esfuerzo que deberá realizar si quiere ganarla, ademas de esto la forma del equipo durante esta temporada ha estado en constante cuestionamiento y no han logrado el rendimiento que han obtenido en campañas anteriores. Chelsea, rival de Real Madrid es la plantilla con menos experiencia de las 4 en estas instancias de competencias internacionales, tiene mayor disponibilidad de su plantilla y sin duda presentan un menor desgaste fisico en lo que va de la temporada gracias a su constante rotación de jugadores y en el ambito futbolístico durante esta temporada han ido de menos a mas logrando estar en buena forma, lo que los ha llevado a estar en esta instancia, pero es cuestionable que si sea suficiente para lograr ganar el campeonato. En esta llave creo que la experiencia pesara a pesar de las diferentes situaciones y Real Madrid tiene unas 60% de probabilidades de pasar. 
La llave entre Manchester City y PSG a mi parecer es la "final anticipada" ambos son plantillas con indiscutible experiencia, ambos se encuentran en gran forma, sin embargo Manchester City a mi parecer llega con un menor desgaste de la Premier League gracias a la ventaja de puntos que ha logrado, su extensa plantilla y constante rotación. Por lo tanto, PSG en estos ámbitos se ve levemente en desventaja, ya que tiene un desgaste mayor y una plantilla con menor numero de jugadores de primer nivel por posición. Manchester City tiene un 65% de probabilidades de pasar de fase. Por ultimo, cualquiera de los dos finalistas tendrá una posibilidad del 50% de campeonar. Hago este supuesto debido a que es una instancia tan importante que diferencias en los factores que mencione anteriormente no son determinantes. 
Por lo tanto las probabilidades quedan: 
Chelsea- Manchester city: 0.65x0.4= 26% ganador ingles
Chelsea - PSG: 0.4x0.35= 7% ganador ingles y 7% ganador frances
Manchester city - Real Madrid: 0.65x0.6= 19,5% ganador ingles y 19,5% ganador español
PSG- Real Madrid: 0.35x0.6= 10.5% ganador español y 10.5% ganador frances.
Sumando los coeficientes:
Inglaterra: 53%
Francia: 17%
España: 30%
La probabilidad de que no exista un ganador en esta edición de la competición lo tomo como despreciable ya que, incluso en la edición anterior en un escenario bastante mas incierto se logró terminar , por lo tanto este año creo que de todas maneras se lograra tambien.

Ya conociendo los semifinalistas de la famosa Liga de campeones Chelsea, Manchester City, Real Madrid y PSG. Estoy haciendo esta predicción siendo un fanático de esta copa, alguien que ve todos los partidos sin falta y cree en todas las "leyes no escritas" como la "ley del ex", "no se toca la copa antes de ganarla", etc. 
A mi parecer, los favoritos para ganar esta copa eran el Manchester City y el PSG, dos multimillonarios que han irrumpido recientemente en el fútbol europeo con una importante inyección económica. Por otra parte, esta el Real Madrid con el que pocos contaban pero que siempre da la talla en ‘su’ Champions y un Chelsea que en teoría tiene menos potencial que los otros tres semifinalistas pero que ha dejado por el camino entre otros, al Atlético.(fuente: https://www.sportytrader.es/pronosticos/futbol/europa/liga-de-campeones-8/) 
Sin embargo, nos podemos dar cuenta que los dos favoritos se enfrentan entre sí, es decir, uno de ellos quedará en el camino a la final. Hoy en día, el PSG cuenta con más "Jugadores estrellas", eliminaron al actual campeón que pintaba como un equipo invensible, y un hambre de ganar la copa después de haberla perdido el año pasado, por lo que creo firmemente que serán superiores al mega proyecto de Guardiola. 
En la otra llave se enfrentaran los "Merengues" a los "Blues". El Chelsea, a pesar de estar dando una buena campaña en Inglaterra y en esta edición de Champions, a mi parecer no está al nivel del Real Madrid, principalmente por la experiencia que tienen en la copa cada uno, a mi parecer pasarán los blancos a la final para enfrentarse a un favorito. 
Si es que esto pasa, se enfrentaría el PSG (como favorito) al Real Madrid. Aquí, por ser una final, puede pasar cualquier cosa, sin embargo existe una teoría de que existen equipos coperos, ningún otro equipo ha jugado, ni ganado, tantas finales de Champions como los 'merengues'. Los blancos han disputado un total de 15. De esas 15, el Madrid sólo ha perdido tres: la de 1962 ante el Benfica (5-3), la de 1964 frente al Inter (3-1) y la de 1981 ante el Liverpool (1-0). Esto hace que el actual rey de Europa tenga un magnífico balance de 12 victorias y tres derrotas en las finales de Champions.(es.besoccer.com). El PSG por su parte nunca ha ganado esta copa, nunca había llegado a una final hasta el año pasado y varias veces había sido eliminado teniendo el puesto de "favorito".
En conclusión, siento que los equipos ingleses tienen la mitad de posibilidades que el otro par, por lo que al ser 2 suman el mismo porcentaje que España y Francia. Se puede afirmar que el PSG actualmente tiene un "mejor futbol" y mejores jugadores que el Real Madrid, por lo que pueden ser los favoritos también en esta final, pero tomando en cuenta lo que se mencionó anteriormente, los blancos tienen experiencia en esta copa, son los poseedores de más Champions y poseen a un DT que consiguió 3 de estas copas de manera consecutiva. Puede ser que la experiencia, se sobreponga al poderío del equipo Frances.

Quedan 4 equipos peleando por levantar la anhelada "orejona" y ser el mejor equipo de Europa. Estos 4 equipos, se dividen entre 3 países, España, que tiene como representante al Real Madrid, Inglaterra que tiene como respresentantes a Chelsea y Manchester City y Francia que tiene como representante al Paris Saint Germain.
Las llaves de semifinales son Chelsea vs Real Madrid, en donde por historia en campeonatos europeos el favorito debiese ser el Real Madrid y visto el repunte que ha tenido en La Liga y por la reciente eliminación del Liverpool equipo Inglés, es el favorito. En la otra llave no hay un favorito claro Paris Saint Germain es el actual vicampeon y acaba de eliminar al vigente campeón de la Chapions League, por el otro lado está el Manchester City que es el actual líder en la Premier League y cuenta con un de los mejores planteles del mundo, de este duelo puede resultar con un leve favoritismo el PSG. Al quedar 2 equipos ingleses le otrogué una probabilidad de 40%, el Real Madrid representante de España lo considero como favorito, por la historia y el como juega en las instancias de la Champions League, por último el PSG que es el actual vicempeon y verdugo del actual campeon de Champions, asoma como candidato claro a ganar la actual Champions League.

Inglaterra tiene la primera opción por tener 2 equipos, siendo el más probable el Manchester City, ya que llega con el envión anímico de romper la maldición de los cuartos de final, además de harta ventaja en su liga por lo que puede descansar a sus jugadores. Al Chelsea le veo menos opciones por la inexperiencia, pero es el con mejor funcionamiento actual. Las lesiones del Real Madrid me preocupan, además de que está peleando también la Liga. EL PSG creo que si gana su semifinal puede ganarlo, pero en defensa contra el City pueden sufrir.

Esta predicción se podría desglosar de la siguiente manera dados los 4 equipos que están en competencia actualmente en la etapa de semifinales: Paris Saint Germain (France) 35%, Manchester City (England) 30%, Real Madrid (Spain) 20% y Chelsea (England) 15%. Esta predicción es realizada en base al momento futbolístico de cada equipo, evaluado en su posición actual en sus respectivas ligas, rivales vencidos en los últimos partidos en la competición para alcanzar las semifinales y composición del plantel.
En primer lugar, está el PSG, que está en un muy buen momento en su liga, posicionándose en el segundo lugar a 4 puntos del primero, además eliminaron al actual campeón, el Bayern Munich, en cuartos de final y al Barcelona en octavos, tienen en su delantera a jugadores muy desequilibrantes como son Mbappé y Neymar, y la edición pasada de la Champions lograron llegar a la final. En segundo lugar, está el Manchester City, quienes también están en un muy buen momento, ya que en la Premier League están punteros a 11 puntos del segundo, tienen un equipo consolidado, con grandes individualidades, jugadores jóvenes muy prometedores y un técnico con mucha experiencia como es Pep Guardiola, para llegar a la semifinal tuvieron que eliminar al Borussia Dortmund, equipo de características similares a las anteriormente descritas. En tercer lugar, tenemos al Real Madrid, equipo que no ha sobresalido tanto esta temporada, pero que se encuentra segundo en su liga a 1 punto del primero, viene de ganar el Clásico Español, derrotar al Liverpool en cuartos y tiene como director técnico a Zinedine Zidane, con quien ganaron 3 Champions seguidas de las últimas 5 jugadas y poseen muchas figuras de nivel mundial. En último lugar se encuentra el Chelsea, equipo de no muy buen presente en su liga, marchando 5 en la tabla, llegó a esta instancia tras vencer al Atlético de Madrid en octavos y tiene varias figuras jóvenes con mucho potencial.
Dados todos estos antecedentes es que se definieron los porcentajes iniciales, entregándole una mayor probabilidad de ganar a un equipo de Francia, pero atribuyéndole una mayor probabilidad de éxito a un equipo inglés porque hay 2 equipos posibles en esta ronda. A mi parecer quien gane la semifinal entre Manchester City y PSG será el campeón de esta edición del campeonato.
532 thinks much less of PSG than the crowd - https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/soccer-predictions/champions-league/

First, I took the odds of outright wins for each of the last 4 teams from Betsson, William Hill and bet365 - changed them to probability, and took an average which gave me the following: PSG (France) - 0.2339
Man City (England) - 0.4349
Real Madrid (Spain) - 0.2109
Chelsea (England) - 0.1818 Adding the above would give you 1.06, probably the padding for the betting house to always have a piece of the winning. So then I normalized the values as percentages. PSG (France) - 22.03%
Man City (England) - 40.97%
Real Madrid (Spain) - 19.87%
Chelsea (England) - 17.13% Then I looked at stats about the 4 teams in this year's Champions League: 1. Goals for
2. Goals against
3. Win mathes
4. Lost matches
5. Winning streak for the past 4 matches This in order to verify the validity of the betting houses odds, and it turns out Chelsea might be underrated, so I decided to increase the percentage I give on Chelsea, hence England.

Dados los 4 equipos que están en semifinales, tenemos 2 equipos de Inglaterra, 1 de Francia y 1 de España.
Analizando los estados de los equipos y los planteles de jugadores que proponen, además del peso histórico de cada club en esta competición, se hacen las estimaciones anteriores.
El Manchester City presenta un gran plantel con excelentes jugadores y vienen en un buen momento, ganando 7 de sus últimos 8 partidos con equipos de gran calibre. Por otro lado el Chelsea viene con una temporada mas irregular, pero con jugadores juveniles que prometen mucho y son muy desequilibrantes. Por lo anterior se le atribuye un 40% de probabilidad de que gane un equipo de Inglaterra, ya que tienen 2 de 4 posibles equipos que ganen la copa, pero no se le atribuye la mitad de la posibilidad ya que el City no ha tenido experiencias en etapas finales de esta competición y el Chelsea no está en un momento tan fuerte competitivamente.
Posteriormente tenemos al PSG por parte de Francia, quienes vienen con un excelente equipo y de los mejores planteles ofensivos del planeta. Vienen con buen momento competitivo ya que eliminaron dos grandes equipos como lo son el Bayern y el Barcelona, por lo que vienen potentes y con grandes posibilidades de ganar la copa. Por lo mismo se le otorgó un 35%.
Por último el Real Madrid, quienes tienen un plantel no tan competitivo como otras veces, y vienen de una presentación de juego contra el Liverpool sin mucho destello, sin embargo son un equipo de gran peso en esta competición, que siempre se pone a la altura en momentos importantes, por lo anterior se le entrega un 25%.

Inglaterra tiene una alta probabilidad ya que tiene 2 integrantes en las semifinales. Por una parte esta el Chelsea el cual según su nivel en los últimos años, la juventud y calidad de su plantilla es el equipo con menos opciones de ganar la Champions con una probabilidad de 10%. Por la otra parte esta el Manchester City, equipo que tiene el mejor plantel de los que quedan en competición, sin embargo, no tiene experiencia en esta copa y los últimos años han demostrado que se achican en los momentos definitorios, por esto le estimo una probabilidad de 25% de ser campeón. 
Francia por su parte tiene al PSG el cual ya llego a la final del año pasado y en esta edición ha eliminado a 2 equipos muy fuertes, el Barcelona y el Bayern de Múnich (último campeón y era el favorito para quedarse con esta). Además tiene un gran plantel, con un arquero de experiencia y mucha seguridad en esta competición, acompañados por la ofensiva más fuerte actualmente, comandada por Mbappe y Neymar. Es por esto que su probabilidad de ganar sería de un 30%.
Por último, en España esta el Real Madrid que es el equipo más grande de la historia y el mayor ganador de esta competición por una amplia diferencia (13 veces campeón). Este año el Real Madrid cuenta con un plantel de menor nivel que el PSG y el Manchester City, sin embargo, es el equipo que ha demostrado durante los últimos 7 años que en estas instancias finales y definitorias son los más grandes. Es por esto, dada la historia pasada, actual y el rival que le toca en las semifinales (el Chelsea que como dijimos es el más débil), que el Real Madrid es el equipo con mayores probabilidades de ser campeón de esta Champions con un 35%.

https://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2021/statistics/round=2001252/clubs/kind=goals/index.html#order=4asc Average goals per game - goals conceded per game = difference * difficulty of opposition so far (easy 0 - 1 difficult ) =
(Just statistics from champions league, not domestic) Chelsea 1.9 - 0.3 = 1.6*(0.65) = 1.04
Man City 2.1 - 0.3 = 1.8*(0.65) = 1.17
Paris 2.1 - 1.1 = 1*(0.85) = 0.85
Real Madrid 1.8 - 1.1 = 0.7*(0.75) = 0.525 Total 'score' = 3.585 Scores of nation added up / total score ... England:
1.04 + 1.17 = 2.21 / 3.585 = 61.2%
France:
0.85 / 3.585 = 23.7%
Spain:
0.49 / 3.585 = 13.7%

I'm not a traditional soccer fan, but with every soccer question I get to sit in with my buddy and his group text of rabid, worldwide fanatics. Being an outsider is fun, because the research process is started with as fresh of a perspective as possible. Reminds me of the horse race question last year.
As we can see with the crowd consensus, there is a bit of a lag...
All the German teams are out of the competition.
Slight miscalculation on the final results. Same reasoning as below.

As expected tonight. Oddly PSG's chances reduced slightly as I feel they had a better chance of beating Dortmund than MC.
I make it a 39% chance of an all English final, and 86% chance of one of the two English clubs getting thru.
theoretical chance of two english clubs getting to final so logically 50% chance however Real Madrid look to be playing the best football and without key players also Paris looking very good.

Alemanes: Dortmund.
Franceses: PSG.
Ingleses: M. City, Liverpool y Chelsea.
Españoles: R. Madrid. Estoy haciendo esta predicción  en el minuto 35 del primer tiempo de los partidos Liverpool-R. Madrid y B. Dortmund-M. City,  y considerando también que ya clasificó tanto el PSG y el Chelsea a semifinales el día de ayer. Yo creo que el candidato mas probable será el PSG (Francia) con un 35%, ya que esta pasando por un muy buen momento futbolístico, y además de haber sido el subcampeón de la edición pasada, acaba de eliminar al Bayern (Alemania), campeón de la edición pasada. Es por esto que es el actual favorito para llevarse "La Orejona". Luego, vendrían los equipos ingleses ( Chelsea, Liverpool y M.City ) con 30%, ya que a pesar de tener actualmente mas equipos en competencia, tanto el Chelsea como el Liverpool no están rindiendo del todo como se esperaba, especialmente el Liverpool debido a la gran cantidad de lesionados que presenta, por lo que no los veo como candidatos al título.  El M.City por su parte, en caso de pasar a semifinales tendría que enfrentar al PSG, en donde creo que el equipo francés tiene mas chances de pasar a la final. Inglaterra gana porcentaje por cantidad de equipos, no por talento. En tercer lugar vendría el Real Madrid (España), ya que en caso de clasificar a semifinales (va ganando 3-1 en el global ante el Liverpool), le tocaría al Chelsea, a quien debería derrotar fácilmente. Luego en una eventual final, creo que podría vencer al Dortmund y al M. City, pero caería ante el PSG. Por último estaría el Dortmund (Alemania), a quién considero como la cenicienta de los equipos que quedan, ya que es un equipo menos competitivo en comparación a los demás. En caso de eliminar al M.City (van 2-2, pero clasificando el Dortmund por goles de visita), le tocará ante el imponente PSG en semifinales, por lo que no le veo chances de clasificar a una eventual final, además de que tiene que resistir todavía todo el segundo tiempo a los peligrosos ataques del M. City para poder clasificar.

After Bayern Munich's elimination, I make England overwhelming favourites to win the CL. I feel MC/Pep will not make the mistakes they have previously made and will get through Dortmund tomorrow, then beat PSG in the semi. The bottom half of the draw is weaker for me.

Possible finals:
ManCity - Real Madrid/FC Chelsea
Bayern, Dortmund and Porto lost the quarter final first leg this week, so it is difficult for them to get through.
PSG win tonight is a big plus for MC.

Serge Gnabry, FC Bayern München's other important forward, has tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 and, although feeling well, will not be to participate. He will likely be watching the match on TV in isolation.
Weighting for volume, although Liverpool is likely a longshot.

FC Bayern München's crucial player Robert Lewandowski is injured and will not be able to participate in the home game on 07 April and most likely not even in the road game on 13 April. It appears to make things a lot easier for Paris SG.
I have not followed CL almost at all. The forecast is based on hunches and the number of remaining teams from different countries.
I felt lonely, being the only one seeing more than a few percents for Porto. Reduced them to 2%, and should have done so earlier.

Re-evaluated after QF/SF draws. Heavily skewed to England with 3 teams and the possibility of an English final. I think BM are slight favourites ahead of MC (largely due to historic mistakes by MC/Mr. Guardiola in these types of situation). However, the unbalanced nature of the draw with arguable the four strongest sides in the same half means a team in comparatively poor form (RM for example) can avoid the 'hot' teams and only need to win a one off final. My chart gives Porto a 4% chance, but overriding as I do not see this happening. It also suggests a 70% chance of the winner coming from the top half (BM, BD, PSG, MC). Chelsea are best of the rest with 1 chance in 8.

Remaining teams by country: England - 3 Man City, Liverpool, Chelsea
Germany - 2 Bayern Munich, Dortmund
Spain - 1 Real Madrid
France - 1 PSG
Porto -  1 Portugal By 538 probabilities [1] we get: England = 36 + 18 + 11 = 65
Germany = 16 + 4 = 20
Spain = 10
France = 4
Another Country = 1

I'm surprised how poorly 538 rates Madrid, Bayern, and Dortmund, so I'll be slightly kinder to Germany and Spain than they are. 
[1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/soccer-predictions/champions-league/
Little hope outside of Bayern to make it to final round, and compete with an English team
bayen still must be favourite with Real possible finalist also given draw. england could have 2 in to the final so that must boost percentage.

Assuming equal winning probability for each team and adjusting for the present of qualified teams and the schedule

In the round of 16 each country has the following amount of teams:
Germany - 4 (25%)
Spain - 4 (25%)
England - 3 (19%)
Italy - 3 (19%)
France - 1 (6%)
Portugal - 1 (6%) Given form, history, resources, and the draw, I think you can reasonably adjust these percentages as I have done in this forecast. My thinking for the adjustments is:
The chances of Porto, the only team from 'another country' left, beating Juventus I believe are small, and even smaller that they will then go on to beat 3 more top-tier teams who are assumed to be of a different standard. Though not impossible, of course, I believe it is reasonable to attribute 1% to them. Bayern Munich I believe have a very good chance of winning it themselves, having won it last year, not losing at all in the group stage, and currently 7 points ahead in their domestic league. I would give them a 20% chance of winning it at this stage. Mönchengladbach's chances I think are far lower, given their relative team strength and form (5th in the Bundesliga), and tougher R16 draw (vs Man City), I think a 2% chance is fair for them. Borussia Dortmund are even lower in the Bundesliga, but their Group Stage performance was stronger and thus have an easier R16 draw - 5%. RB Leipzig are 2nd in the Bundesliga, their group stage performance was strong and they play an out-of-form and injury-suffering Liverpool in R16, though they do not have as much Champs league experience - 6%. Total for Germany = 33% Of Spain's 3 main contenders - Atleti, RM, Barca - Atleti are the most in-form, and have a winnable (though not easy) R16 game vs Chelsea. Barca have had a poor season though are bouncing back, and they and RM have buckets of CL experience. RM have an 'easier' draw in R16 vs Atalanta. I think a 15% chance of one of these three teams winning it is fair. Sevilla add to that with a lower 2% - great at winning UEFA cups, 4th in the league, and an even-ish draw could see them into next round but I don't think they have the squad quality to go all the way. Spain = 17%. English teams have recently done very well in the CL, making 50% of finalists in the last 3 years. However, Liverpool (twice finalists recently, 6 times champions) are struggling to find form this season and are suffering from major injuries. Chelsea are having similar form issues, and lack the experience and team cohesion (young and new team, with a young a new manager) to go all the way. Manchester City are a very strong team and have come close many times, though Pep Guardiola seems to have a tactical block when it gets to the latter stages of this competition. However, all three are still very strong teams and on paper could beat most teams 'on their day'. I would give 8% to Liverpool, 5% to Chelsea, and 12% to Man City. England - 25% Of the Italian teams left in the CL, none are currently in the domestic top 3. This weighs against them for form, and focus - Juventus will want to focus on not ending their title-winning streak, and Atalanta and Lazio will want to ensure they are in next year's CL. Lazio and Atalanta have very difficult drawn against BM and RM respectively, and probably amount to a 4% between them. Juventus are a stronger team and have more experience, and will probably beat Porto, but will fail later on as they pay attention to the league - 7%. PSG are the only French team left, but I like their chances. They came second last year and won their group stage. Their R16 is difficult against a resurgent Barca, but given their form and focus (the CL is an elusive goal for the club and board as they cruise to a domestic league title each year), I think they warrant a 13% chance of winning. There will be a 20-21 final, in 2020 they postponed until they could play it and will do that again if necessary.

About a month after the draw, it is a good chance to revisit the current forms of the Champions League teams to see how they have been doing as we look forward to the start of Champions League round of 16 in February.
The Spanish teams are showing a bit of a dip in play across the board. Atletico still leads the league, but was upset in the Copa del Rey and have not looked the dominant buzzsaw previously. Barcelona has caught fire, but recently had a meltdown, especially from Messi, in the Spanish Super Cup final. Real Madrid has struggled a bit, losing in the semifinal of the Spanish Super Cup and struggling to get results in league play. Sevilla has been rounding into form and sits 4th in the La Liga table.
The English teams left in the tournament look to be faltering as well. Chelsea just suffered a demoralizing defeat to Leicester in league play, Liverpool is struggling to keep pace with Man United, and Man City is playing better, but has suffered from some COVID issues the last month.
Germany has also seen some faltering from its top teams in Dortmund and Bayern. PSG in France, same issue. In Italy, the three teams remaining are mid-upper table.
All this to say, some of the more "on fire" teams in Europe right now are no longer in the competition. These recent lulls in the teams still in could be the winter-time blues, squad rotation, and strategic positioning before Champions League kicks back off. However, due to recent play, I've adjusted forecasts for this question in a minor manner to reflect.

England: 
- Liverpool 8
- ManCity 8
- Chelsea 5 France:
- Paris 8 Germany:
- Munich 8
- Leipzig 7
- Mönchengladbach 4
- Dortmund 7 Italy:
- Turin 8
- Rom 4
- Bergamo 4 Spain
- Barcelona 8
- Real Madrid 7
- Atletico Madrid 5
- Sevilla 4 Another Country
- Porto 4 Base rate: 6.25% average for each team

Bayern ropey but time and time again they come good when it matters so trying not to overreact. Liverpool without VVD are not the same and Chelsea are way off the pace. Worried underweighted Spain but hard to see past Bayern or Man City.

Given the current problems I am increasing the chances of a cancelled tournament a little.

Expected participants of the quarter finals 2020/21 (after the games RoS 16 Feb through 17 Mar 2021): FC Bayern München
FC Sevilla
Manchester City
FC Liverpool
Athletico Madrid
Juventus Turin
Real Madrid
Fc Barcelona

Remaining teams :
- 4 Spain (Atlético, Real Madrid, Barcelona, Sevilla)
- 4 Germany (Mönchengladbach, Bayern, Dortmund, Leipzig)
- 3 England (Man City, Chelsea, Liverpool)
- 3 Italy (Lazio, Juventus, Atalanta)
- 1 France (PSG)
- 1 Portugal (Porto) If all teams had equal odds of winning we would have:
- Spain & Germany : 25%
- England & Italy : 18.75%
- France & Portugal : 6.25% Adjusting to remove bookmaker margin, the William Hill odds of nationality of winner gives :
- England: 37%
- Germany: 28%
- Spain: 17%

- France: 7%
- Portugal: 1%
Source : https://sports.williamhill.com/betting/en-gb/football/competitions/OB_TY344/UEFA-Champions-League/outrights/OB_MG14628959/Nationality-Of-Winner English teams are favored because they have a much better draw for the round of 16.
Based on my knowledge of football and this competition it looks like William Hill slightly :
- Overrates english teams
- Underrates spanish teams and underdogs (especially Porto, Atalanta, Lazio) Given that the 2020 edition had a winner with what was close to the worst imaginable conditions, it seems ok to attribute a 1% probability for no final winner.
It looks like the winner will come from England, Germany, or Spain. It's too early to be any more precise than that.

Whilst Bayern Munich are still strong favourites in my opinion, the sacking of Thomas Tuchel and potential appointment of Mauricio Pochettino by PSG leads me to significantly increase their chances of a CL win. Given Mr. Pochettino took an unfancied Tottenham team to the CL final only two years ago, and the quality of attacking player available, it is possible he may be able to whip the team into shape to focus on a 'historic' CL victory for the French side. I will re-evaluate if/when he is appointed and the team have played!

England and Germany seem to have the best chance going into round of 16. England has two legitimate title contenders (Man City and Liverpool) while Germany has one (reinging champion Bayern). Germany has three other teams in the round of 16 and England has one more but they all have diminishing odds of making the final. Spain has four teams through the round of 16 but only Barcelona has been playing at level that makes a title run possible. France's odds with PSG would go up with a big Jan transfer window but right now their path looks challenging.c

Just in case the new virus strain will continue to produce bad news, football is surely a low priority. I see it as a real option that the Champions League will be sacrificed, e.g. for the sake of enabling a safe 2021 UEFA Euro Championship.
Thus, 13% on "no winner" for the time being.

English teams look the best equipped to tackle Bayern Munich, Liverpool and Man city will come strong. Barcelona and Real are way off the pace in my opinion. Athletico are Spain's best bet. After the completion of the Group stage, the breakdown of countries with teams in the round of 16 is as follows:
England - 3 (Chelsea, Liverpool, Man City)
France - 1 (PSG)
Germany - 4 (Bayern, Leipzig, M'Gladbach, Dortmund)
Italy - 3 (Juventus, Lazio, Atalanta)
Spain - 4 (Real Madrid, Atletico Madrid, Barcelona, Sevilla)
Another Country - 1 (Porto - Portugal) Germany has arguably the most number of chances to win the Champions League along with one of the best teams in FC Bayern (who has a favorable match-up against Lazio from Italy). Dortmund also had a favorable draw, matching up against the weakest of the Spanish teams left in the draw (Sevilla). M'Gladbach and Leipzig have challenging draw of which neither are favored to advance (odds based on DraftKings). Therefore, into the round of 8, I project two German teams (or 25% of the teams representing Germany in the quarterfinals).
England has 3 teams in the Round of 16, and all three are currently favored to advance (Chelsea over Atletico Madrid, Man City over M'Gladbach, Liverpool over Leipzig). Assuming favorites advance, England would have 37.5% of teams in the quarterfinals. I project at least 2 teams, with Atletico vs. Chelsea a toss-up; in fact, I will project that this is a slight upset in favor of Atletico based upon their domestic success this season and their style of play conducive to Champions League football.
Spain has four teams in the Round of 16, but only one favorite (Real Madrid over Atalanta). Barcelona has a challenging match-up with PSG and it will be critical to monitor Neymar's current ankle injury (which is now projected to be weeks rather than months). Sevilla and Atletico Madrid have already been discussed and, at this point, I only project two advancements from Spain into the Round of 8 (the two teams from Madrid).
Italy has three teams in the Round of 16, but two are heavy underdogs (Lazio and Atalanta) where Juventus is a heavy favorite over FC Porto. At this point, I project only Juventus advancing.
France only has PSG in the Round of 16, but a very strong PSG team. PSG drew a tough challenge in Barcelona, but at this time, I will project them to advance in the competition.
Portugal is the only other country represented, and Porto drew Juventus as discussed. I do not see them going through, but since there is still a chance, they are forecasted at 1%.
I previously discussed the possibility of no winner; while I maintain that a winner will be crowned, there is still a chance that one might not and so that also remains at 1%.
PSG was a big loser in 538s predictions post round of 16 draw, 7% --> 4%, 6th to 10th likely.  Man City increased at the top, 24% -->27%

Bayern München
FC Sevilla
Manchester City
FC Liverpool
FC Chelsea
Juventus Turin
Real Madrid
FC Barcelona to be around for the quarter final. Very tough lots for all German teams except Bayern München.

I see every group winner advancing except for Chelsea, but Barcelona could very well beat PSG. Prob close to 50/50. Biggest change teamwise for me is Juventus, I think they have a decent shot after beating Barcelona handily in the Camp Nou. It helps they get Porto in the ro16 as well.

Spain = 20% = 70(1/8) + 30(3/8)
England = 26% = 70(3/8) + 30(0/8)
Italy = 16% = 70(1/8) + 30(2/8)
France = 9% = 70(1/8) + 30(0/8)
Other = 4% = 70(0/8) + 30(1/8) Looking at the list of clubs ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_European_Cup_and_UEFA_Champions_League_finals#By_club I will reduce Italy's chances based on their 2021 teams ->

Under COVID conditions this past summer, the competition was able to find a way to finish up and award a champion. I forecast that the same will hold true in 2021 as long as the conditions are not excessively worse than the initial pandemic outbreak, although there is always a chance.
My initial forecast is based on the strength of teams in Europe and what appears to be a vastly superior FC Bayern Munchen side compared to the rest of European football. However, the group stage wraps up today and the final 16 teams will be established.
My initial forecasting reflects the strength of the different federations and the quality of teams still remaining in the competition.
I forecast Germany with the best chance of winning, primarily on the fact that they arguably tout the best team in all of Europe (FC Bayern) as well as two other teams guaranteed advancement (Borussia Dortmund and Leipzig). A fourth could advance as well depending on today's results (Borussia M'Gladbach). 
I forecast England as the next highest with three teams advancing as well in Liverpool, Man City, and Chelsea. Their depth quality is stronger than Germany, but the top team of FC Bayern gives Germany a significant edge in my opinion. Manchester United was knocked out yesterday so the most amount of clubs England can have in the final 16 are three.
Spain, home of two of the largest and best clubs in Real Madrid and FC Barcelona, are forecasted with the third best chance. Both of those teams have had a rough run of form lately, especially in La Liga. However, thus far, only Barcelona and Sevilla have qualified; today, Atletico Madrid and Real Madrid have a chance to advance, but both could be knocked out as well. If four teams from Spain advance, that could up their forecast significantly.
Forecasted with the fourth best probability is Italy. They have a very strong top club in Juventus and have also qualified Lazio as well. Atalanta and Inter Milan have a shot to qualify today and that could significantly increase their forecast based on numbers alone as well.
I have France forecasted fifth. France has a giant in PSG, but that is the only club they are sending into the final 16. They have had a poor run in the competition historically, although they did make the final last year. Based on numbers of teams and probability alone pushes France down a lot.
Lastly, I have 'another country' and no winner as a remote shot. Based on awarding a winner last year in the final, especially due to financial considerations, I see there being a winner this year in a final somehow as well. 'Another country' is an interesting case. In the last 25 years, a team outside the big five European federations won the Champions League once - 2003-2004 by FC Porto (Portugal). To say this would happen is an outlier. Currently, there only FC Porto is assured of advancing to the round of 16 this year, but there are a few other teams (Shakhtar Donetsk - Ukraine, FC Salzburg - Austria, Ajax - Netherlands) with a chance to advance. Realistically, Ajax and FC Porto are the only two clubs with a remote chance to win the competition, and that would be seen as a major upset and highly unlikely. But a chance nonetheless.
My challenge in this forecast is my bias toward Real Madrid (my favorite team) and Spain in general based on my beliefs, so tempering those biases is important in my forecasts here.
Starting with five thirty eight as my anchor.

England has three contenders (Manchesters and Liverpool, rougly equally strong. I am giving 10% chance each). Germany has two contenders (BVB and Bayern). I give Bayern 15% because they are really strong and current champions. France (PSG, 10%. Strong but no Champions League history) Italy (Juve, 10%. Strong but has not won in decades) Spain (Real, Atletico, and Barca) I am giving Barca a 5% chance because they are not looking too good.

It will be difficult for any Barcelona players capped to develop a winning mindset to drive the national side, particularly considering the acrimony generated by the presence of their team boss, Barcelona "manager" Koeman.
538 continues to have no faith in the Italians, despite Atalana's win and Lazio being undeafeated
If you see forwards in other European leagues, such as Ibrahimovic, Firmino and others, score, then I really don't believe German teams have a chance, even with Lewandowski, Haaland etc.

Slight downward nudge for Germany (i.e. Bayern) due to Kimmich injury.
That said, it is really too early to make a firm prediction because there is little jeopardy for any of the likely winners in the group phase (perhaps Dortmund would disagree). Also, form and injuries affecting teams in April are more relevant than those picked up now, and may mean someone who misses two months now will be slightly fresher come the later knockout rounds.

Injuries, chaotic fixture congestion, and COVID-19 are having a major impact. Adjusting the predictions for things like the COVID-19 fubar in Serie A (which seems likely to have long-term ramifications), Barca and Real underperforming (though not Athletico), and a rampant Bayern. However, it is still far too soon to make a major shift, especially before the knock-out stage.

PSG may not even make it to the knock out stages and Juventus got destroyed by a mediocre Barca side. Seeing Dortmund and Munich play, I'm raising the odds a German side goes the distance and also upping the odds a Spanish team lifts silverware just because of the depth of talent and number of teams they have in the competition.
538 continues to disagree with the crowd on the Italians and now the French
Again, I used the 538 predictions. Refused to sed zero for "no winner"

Spain rank high for two reasons: first, they have a strong track record of success in the tournament and, second, they have the largest volume of high-quality talent out of any country (thus far this season). Germany, on the other hand, have the reigning champs and arguable favorites this time around, though with COVID who knows what the journey to a repeat would look like. Every team has had some atrocities already this season so there are no clear favorites yet and if it comes down to single elimination you could make a case for virtually any of the big names depending on their path to the cup. Basically, we don't know much yet other than that it is shaping up to be quite an interesting year.

This round of matches saw Juve lose at home to Barca. Neither side appear likely to be contenders.
Bayern look a class apart.
However, given the surge in cases, I now think there is a danger of disruption to the group phase, and as such I now allow for the possibility of no winner, although I still see this as an outlier.

I may have been a bit optimistic for Italy, Juve and Inter both seem pretty disappointing. Italy's chances at a run should be pretty clear by next matchday, with Inter facing Real in Madrid and Atalanta at home vs Liverpool.  Otherwise, Real Madrid's recent upswing (perhaps deserving more than a pt yesterday) and Chelsea's revelation at GK give England and Spain a little boost, along with today's confident win against Leipzig for Man United.

A first stab at this based on early season only:
- England: The only realistic option is MC (Liverpool's loss of VvD, Chelsea defensive ineptitude, MU too inconsistent), and they have a history of finding a way not to win, so a low probability considering the perceived strength of the PL
- France: PSG are the only realistic option, but their loss at home means they are in danger of failing to get out of the group. This will be upgraded if they win @MU or @RBL.
- Germany: BM are likely to remain strong contenders even if they revert to mean and stop winning every game. RBL, Dortmund have outside chances if they get favourable draws in the KO phases
- Italy: Juventus again are the only realistic option (notwithstanding Atalanta's excellent showing last year), but I do not see Pirlo winning it in his first season in a year of some transition, especially given Juve may find themselves in an actual title race for the first time in a while
- Spain: Real are perennial challenges, but have started the group poorly. A win in El Classico will bolster the team, but they are not the force they once were, and I feel the big European heavyweights would be confident in knockout games. Barca still have quality players, but the club is a bit of a mess, so I think they are unlikely, albeit not impossible challengers
I do not see a club outside of the 'Big 5' leagues winning the title because the competition is biased towards them in numbers. Ajax and Porto are probably the only two to consider, the former reaching the SF stage only two years ago, but in my view the chances are negligible.
The 'No-result' option to me is unlikely to be a factor, unless the group phase is stopped. If the groups are finished (and I think they probably will be), I think another Lisbon style tournament will be arranged to satisfy broadcaster demand.

EDIT 28 Oct 2020:
FC Barcelona and FC Sevilla

I really wasn't happy with my first baseline. So decided to use 538's predictions as a point of departure. Guesstimated 1% chance of no final Winner. Allocated the remaining 5% to "Another country". I will update this in the same manner after the next round of matches. I will also check against bookmakers' odds to see if my forecast diverges from theirs

I listed all the teams in competition by country. Gave added weight to those who had won their first match, reduced the weight of those who had lost their first match. Guesstimated a 5% chance of no winner. Next estimate I will refine by looking att historical record of teams in 1,2,3,4 Group position after n games. I could have gone with historical record. Last 20 years would yield: DE 15%, ES 45%, IT 15%, PT 5%, UK 20%.
538 really doesn't like Inter or Juve
The injury to Van Dijk hurts England as does Real's performance vs Shakhtar for Spain. Bayern looks like the favorites after their showing vs Atleti.

Matchday 1 update (summary of 538 UEFA ratings) https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/soccer-predictions/champions-league/ On considering the impact of covid on sporting matches the limited pool of sports am comfortable commenting on (cricket, rugby union, rugby league and Australian rules), there may be a slight suggestion that teams from places with harsher impact on society have preformed better than those who manage the virus well - perhaps this is the freedom of movement, with harsher lockdowns putting a blip in player preparation?  But I'm forcing myself to look for an impact and don't believe there is has been a clear one.
Spain's teams performance and potential continue to rise as does Bayern Munich of Germany.  Initial analysis on Man City and Liverpool seemed to have been a bit high.
Still blindly tracking 538 at this stage

Just ticked Spain down, as the top 2 look vulnerable
Cov id is levelling the playing field so could be a surprise winner
I'll be blindly tracking 538's predictions again, they don't like an Italian winner as much as the crowd.  https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/soccer-predictions/champions-league/

Initial forecast is based entirely on the last 20 years. Spain has won it 9 times, Italy three times, Germany three times, England 4 times, Portugal once, and France 0 times (RIP PSG). I don't see much reason to change it from here so far. Munich won last year but have already shown several issues with depth and defending this year, so I'm not sure they deserve any bump for holding the title currently. It's simply too early to know much about the ultimate outcome at the moment.

England gets a boost from Man City getting back into the UCL after appeal. That gives England two serious shots at winning (Man City and Liverpool) not to mention Chelsea's recent transfer spending should give them an opportunity to make a deep run. Germany has the defending champions (Bayern) who appear to be again one of the three best clubs in the world and a serious threat to repeat. Although the Budesliga is not the deepest league out there, RB Leipzig gives Germany a potential second, although unlikely path to a title. Spain is an interesting case as it has 3 of the 10 best club teams in the world. However, perhaps the golden age of the big 2 is waning a bit.  Although another deep Lyon run is unlikely, PSG remains a serious threat to win the title. Italy has an outside chance with Inter Milan or Juventus. Another country taking the title seems extremely unlikely, The ongoing pandemic provides at least a 10% chance of there being no winner, especially if group stage play gets shut down.
Germany: 8 wins, England: 13 wins, Spain: 18 wins, Italy 12, France: 2 wins, Netherland: 8 wins, Portugal: 6 wins. Neglecting the rest results in N = 67 and the  probability calculated accordingly
The Morata and Suarez transfers plus Barca's rejuvenation (literally) means a slight uptick this early on for Spain. Ditto for Germany with the impressive depth of Bayern and Dortmund's squads.

Top contenders with a realistic shot of winning the Champions League from each country are:

This is definitely one I'll come back to once the competition starts in full, but for now, I'll base my forecast on team performance in the past couple of years. The forecast is a little bit speculative for now, particularly whilst transfers are still happening and we've not seen how these clubs are performing in their leagues. The previous three winners: Bayern, Liverpool, Real, all need to be considered threats. Although, by this point I believe Real Madrid's power is depleting - I think they have an ageing squad, particularly when it comes to key players. Nonetheless, La Liga clubs have won this competition much more than any other nation, so the La Liga champions should always be considered contenders. Bayern and Liverpool have both retained the vast majority of their champions league winning teams, so should still be considered real threats too.  With the COVID induced fixture congestion and issues with positive cases, I think squad depth will prove more important than ever. This favours clubs like Man City who employ successful squad rotation (although City only really do this in attack and their defence will need to be further bolstered to help them stay competitive - Ake is a start and signing Koulibaly would be a bonus). Bayern will miss Thiago and Coutinho, but they still have one of the best benches in club football. Liverpool have had issues with a lack of squad depth, but Minamino has settled in better, making him a viable back up in attack, whilst Thiago adds much needed creativity in Midfield.  There are other competitors to consider. Last year's finalists PSG will be keen to compete again, but I'm doubtful they've made the signings needed to push them the whole way. It's worth considering Chelsea dangerous this season, considering how many new signings they've made, although their shaky start to the Premier League throws some doubt over whether such a freshly assembled squad is ready to really compete.  An Italian team like Juventus or Inter might surprise at the group stages, but for a few years now, the Italian clubs haven't come close to the standard in the rest of Europe. Ditto for clubs in the Portuguese and Dutch leagues, who unfortunately more act as feeder clubs for the giants in the big 5 leagues. Based on this, I think we have the following teams in with a shot: England top competitors: Liverpool and City (potentially Chelsea)
German top competitors: Bayern
Spain top competitors: Real
France potentials: PSG

Base rate  from usual suspects - 2 teams from England, 1 from France, etc Then Another country assumed to provide 2 wild card contenders Lastly, adjusted based on perception of team strengths (gains / losses over transfer period)

This is a question that needs a lot of altering as more games are played and data becomes available. I don't think looking at the historical success of a country is a very reliable benchmark for the future as football changes so much so quickly.  Teams and countries that once dominated Europe are now shadows of themselves E.g Italy - A.C Milan (second-most wins ever with 7 and are not even in the league) Inter Milan (3 wins), Netherlands - Ajax (4 wins). And teams that have never won are up there with the favorites E.g England's Manchester City, France's PSG.  However, looking at the historical success of a country may inform which style of play in domestic leagues is successful. Winner/runner up Spain 18/11

Messi will not want leave without another title. The same goes Ibracadabra, but he will not be able to make up for a whole team. I think the risk of major disturbances in the European Leagues' timetables is considerable, so it might not be quite clear by March/April, who actually will be qualified for the first round, and what size, format and place the final games could take place. Turkey seems odd at the moment for political reasons, there might be a second guess by New Year and a relocation.
